bestBHT.bht: The parable of the ten virgins highlights the distinction between the wise and the foolish in their readiness for the coming of the Bridegroom. The foolish virgins, lacking oil, hurried to obtain some, but found the door shut and their chance for entrance lost. This vivid depiction of almost being saved but ultimately lost serves as a powerful warning. The parable underscores the importance of being prepared and ready for Christ's coming, as those who are ready will be admitted while the door closes for the unprepared.

Henry Alford: For it is not the final coming of the Lord to judgment, when the day of grace will be past, that is spoken of
This feast is the marriage supper of Rev. xix. 7–9 (see also ib. xxi. 2)
after which these improvident ones gone to buy their oil shall be judged in common with the rest of the dead
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: They are sensible of their past folly; they have taken good advice: they are in the act of getting what alone they lacked: a very little more, and they also are ready.
But the Bridegroom comes; the ready are admitted; 'the door is shut,' and they are undone.
How graphic and appalling this picture of one almost saved—but lost!
Albert Barnes: They will be ready who have repented of their sins; who truly believe on the Lord Jesus; who live a holy life; and who wait for his coming.
No more could be admitted to the marriage-feast. So, when the truly righteous shall all be received into heaven, the door will be closed against all others.
There will be no room for preparation afterward.
Marvin Vincent: While they went... while they are going away."
They that were ready... the ready or prepared ones."
John Calvin: At length it follows that the door of the heavenly kingdom will be shut against all who have not made provision, because they failed in the middle of the course.

We must not enter here into minute inquiries, how it is that Christ says that the foolish virgins went to buy for it means nothing else than that all who shall not be ready at the very moment when they shall be called will be shut out from entering into heaven.
...all who shall not be ready at the very moment when they shall be called will be shut out from entering into heaven.
Philip Schaff: They kept up their endeavor to the very last.
They that were ready went in with him to the marriage feast.
The door was shut. No more entrance to the feast.
Archibald T. Robertson: While they were going away, descriptive linear action. Picture of their inevitable folly.
Effective aorist passive indicative, shut to stay shut.
John Gill: And the door was shut: which expresses both the happy and comfortable case of the wise virgins, and the sad and miserable state of the foolish ones." (57 words)

The door being shut, the wise virgins will at once be freed from the disagreeable company of profane sinners, and formal professors; their state and condition will be everlastingly settled, their communion with Christ will be free and uninterrupted, and that, for ever..." (60 words)

The door of faith...and this will be shut when Christ comes; there will be no more preaching; and there is also the door of hope...but when Christ comes, either by death, or at judgment, and finds persons in a graceless state, there is then no hope." (49 words)

bhtAttempts.bht: The parable of the ten virgins in Matthew 25:10 speaks not of the final judgment, but of the wedding feast in Revelation. The five foolish virgins, who lacked sufficient oil, frantically sought to buy more, but were too late. It is a graphic and appalling picture of almost being saved but ultimately lost. The door was shut, and their opportunity to enter the feast was gone. This parable emphasizes the importance of being prepared for the bridegroom's coming, as those who are ready will be admitted while the door remains shut for the unprepared.

In the parable of the ten virgins, the focus is not on the final judgment but on the wedding feast in Revelation. The foolish virgins, lacking sufficient oil, desperately sought to buy more, but it was too late. Their failure to prepare resulted in the door being shut, a graphic and appalling picture of almost being saved but ultimately lost. The parable underscores the importance of readiness, as those who are prepared will gain entry while the unprepared are left outside.

The parable of the ten virgins in Matthew portrays the crucial distinction between the prepared and the unprepared. These foolish virgins, lacking oil, hurried to buy some but found themselves shut out from the wedding feast. It is a powerful illustration of being almost saved but ultimately lost. This parable emphasizes the necessity of readiness, as those who were prepared went in while the door closed for the unprepared. It serves as a reminder of the importance of being spiritually prepared for Christ's coming.

The parable of the ten virgins highlights the distinction between the wise and the foolish in their readiness for the coming of the Bridegroom. The foolish virgins, lacking oil, hurried to obtain some, but found the door shut and their chance for entrance lost. This vivid depiction of almost being saved but ultimately lost serves as a powerful warning. The parable underscores the importance of being prepared and ready for Christ's coming, as those who are ready will be admitted while the door closes for the unprepared.

The parable of the ten virgins portrays the significance of preparedness for the coming of the Bridegroom. The foolish virgins, who lacked oil, sought to buy some but were too late, finding the door shut and their opportunity gone. Their story serves as a striking illustration of almost being saved but ultimately lost. It emphasizes the urgency of readiness, as those who are prepared will be admitted while the door remains shut for the unprepared.
